info.game_comments:
Mark Wales game 6.
Last game of Season 24.

double_jeopardy_round: I WON AN OSCAR, EMMY, TONY & GRAMMY

(1, 1).clue: In 1891 he created his first of more than 30 posters, "Moulin Rouge--La Goulue"

(2, 1).clue: This TV co-hostess was recognized by "The Guiness Book of World Records" as television's most frequent clapper

(3, 1).clue: This "king" of the dinosaurs had a muscular jaw that, it's thought, could rip off 500 pounds of meat at once

(4, 1).clue: Trouble in this former kingdom now part of China captured headlines in March

(5, 1).clue: The basset hound is second only to this dog breed in having the keenest sense of smell

(6, 1).clue: Ifyouaspireto thespire ofa church,it's one of these

(1, 2).clue: His 1892 work "Manao Tupapau" shows a superstitious Tahitian girl who is terrified of a dead spirit

(2, 2).clue: In this 1961 No. 1 hit, "You saw me standing alone / Without a dream in my heart / Without a love of my own"

(3, 2).clue: This plant-eater is the largest, most common & best known of the horned dinosaurs

(4, 2).clue: The Times reported this New Yorker was quitting the presidential race following his defeat in the Florida primary

(5, 2).clue: Famed for its exceptional wool, the Merino sheep was originally developed in this country

(6, 2).clue: Another name for a lottery; there was a famous "Irish" one until 1987

(1, 3).clue: In 1838 Eugene Delacroix painted separate portraits of Chopin & this woman, Chopin's lover

(2, 3).clue: For adults, the U.S. Judo Federation has this rank directly below a black belt

(3, 3).clue: This dinosaur was swift, but not as fast or as smart as in "Jurassic Park"; it did have that scary sickle-like claw, though

(4, 3).clue: Upcoming trials for 9/11 suspects held at this facility were reported in 2008

(5, 3).clue: Species of this creature include the chinstrap & the adelie

(6, 3).clue: An item retained for its sentimental value

(1, 4).clue: From 1948 to 1951, this Fauvist designed & decorated the Chapel of the Rosary in Vence, France

(2, 4).clue: This feline has been strutting to a Henry Mancini soundtrack since the 1960s

(3, 4).clue: The name of the Laplatasaurus honors a river on the border of Uruguay & this country

(4, 4).clue: A tentative deal with producers reported on February 10 proved to be the end of this labor action

(5, 4).clue: Also known as a cattalo, it's the hybrid bovine that results when you breed an American bison & a regular cow

(1, 5).clue: He was known for his readymades such as "L.H.O.O.Q.", a copy of the "Mona Lisa" with a penciled-in mustache & beard

(2, 5).clue: He earned the nickname "Galloping Ghost" after scoring 5 touchdowns in a 1924 college football game

(3, 5).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew reports from the American Museum of Natural History in New York.) The famous 50-foot in the American Museum of Natural History is a dinosaur whose name comes from the Greek for "weight", as in an atmospheric meter

(4, 5).clue: In 2008 the Times covered clashes following this Serbian territory's declaration of independence

(5, 5).clue: The criollo & the hackney are breeds of these

(6, 5).clue: The USS Prime is a prime example of these vessels that clear harbors of dangerous explosives

(1, 1).clue: His universal law of gravitation explained many things, including the action of tides & the motion of comets

(2, 1).clue: In 1962 Oscar loved her in "West Side Story" (& isn't she the first one you think of for the category?)

(3, 1).clue: This last Romanov to rule Russia became the last czar when he was dethroned in 1917

(4, 1).clue: Politician & author of "A History of the English-Speaking Peoples"

(5, 1).correct response: Are You There God? It\'s Me, Margaret

(6, 1).clue: High blood pressure & glaucoma can be treated with metoprolol, one of this "blocker" class of drugs

(1, 2).clue: Robert Boyle invented a vacuum pump & discovered that this does not travel in a vacuum

(2, 2).clue: In 2002 she won an Emmy for a special about Hattie McDaniel, but it's her acting Oscar for "Ghost" you might remember

(3, 2).clue: In the 1780s, when the divine right of royalty was questioned, she said, "I am an aristocrat. It is my profession"

(4, 2).clue: A lake on the New York-Vermont border is named for this explorer who visited the region in 1609

(6, 2).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew airmails us something from The Thunderbirds in Las Vegas, NV.)  Several times in each show, all 6 Thunderbirds, flying 18 inches apart, team up in this formation named for a Greek letter

(1, 3).clue: Lucasian Prof. of Mathematics at Cambridge, he was born on January 8, 1942, 300 years to the day after Galileo's death

(2, 3).clue: In 1982 this butler did it--& got a Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his trouble, for "Arthur"

(3, 3).clue: 3 Russian czars were named Fyodor, which corresponds to this name in English

(4, 3).clue: Diplomat & premier of China from 1949 to 1976 (one spelling)

(6, 3).clue: Charlton Heston played a survivor of an apocalyptic war in this 1971 thriller

(1, 4).clue: In 1932 James Chadwick discovered this subatomic particle that appears in all atoms except hydrogen

(2, 4).clue: The 1961 Grammy for Best Comedy Performance went to "An Evening with" him "and Elaine May"

(3, 4).clue: At 43 years, the reign of this founder of the Russian navy was the longest of any czar

(4, 4).clue: Lucy Walter was this English king's mistress during his exile in the 1600s in Holland

(6, 4).clue: This triple star system is the brightest celestial object in a certain horsey constellation

(1, 5).clue: Known for the second law of thermodynamics, this lord helped with the laying of the transatlantic cable

(2, 5).clue: The 1958 Tony for Dramatic Actress was bestowed on this "First Lady of American Theatre" for her role in "Time Remembered"

(3, 5).clue: The 1604 invasion against this czar by the False Dmitri & his Polish troops marked the start of the "Time of Troubles"

(4, 5).clue: In 1948 he testified to congress that Alger Hiss had illegally passed him official documents

(6, 5).clue: Found in blood serum, they contain the antibodies of the immune system

(0, 0).clue: Meaning "painful", it literally refers to the type of pain inflicted on Jesus & on the followers of Spartacus
